awd_titl_txt: Programming Ink Deposition Dynamically: The New Science of Direct Ink Writing
awd_abstract_narration:
Direct Ink Writing (DIW) is a class of three-dimensional (3D) printing that builds a 3D object by depositing functional and/or structural liquid materials (ink) onto a substrate in a layer-by-layer approach.  This award supports fundamental research to provide new knowledge for control of ink deposition on substrates or previously printed layers. The research will advance DIW technology toward a higher achievable resolution, more flexible ink design, higher print quality, and a much wider choice of substrates. DIW has applications in a number of industries, including health care, electronics, automotive, aerospace and defense, and therefore this research directly impacts economic welfare and national security. Furthermore, the developed knowledge of ink deposition control could be applied to almost any droplet- or liquid filament-based process. 45.6 percent of undergraduate students in the UIC College of Engineering are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. The PIs will work actively to involve underrepresented minority students in workshops, seminars, and mini-symposiums that are created from this project. Research outcomes will be incorporated into three engineering courses at UIC, the Engineering Summer Camp at UIC, and the 3D printing learning modules for Women In Engineering (WIEP) K-12 outreach programs.  

Dynamic and localized control of ink wettability on substrates or previously printed layers is pivotal for addressing current tolerance and repeatability challenges and advancing DIW technologies. The objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that wetting properties of leaky dielectric liquid droplets/filaments on substrates change dynamically when an electric field is applied, thus enabling accurate direct writing of inks on a wide range of substrates. The applied electric field is programmed in a pixel-by-pixel and layer-by-layer way, so that it manipulates ink deposition at any location, in any layer, and on any substrate. The research team will perform multiphysics modeling and experiments to understand the ink electrowetting dynamics, design and construct electric mask (e-Mask) generation systems, establish a novel e-Mask assisted DIW system and process, and assess the new DIW system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Direct Ink Writing (DIW) is a class of three-dimensional (3D) printing that builds a 3D object by depositing functional and/or structural liquid materials onto a substrate in a layer-by-layer approach.  The range of materials deposited can include metals, ceramics and polymers, electronically and optically functional materials as well as biological materials including living cells. A wide variety of applications from flexible electronic fabrication to functional tissue printing has been demonstrated. However, grand challenges still exist in aspects of quality, resolution, and ink design for printability.  This project aims to study the control of wettability of inks on substrates or previously printed layers through applying an external electric field.

 

Outcomes- Intellectual merits:

 This project established the fundamental knowledge of the liquid ink extrusion, deposition, and wetting dynamics under different electric fields. Mechanisms for integrating electric fields into direct ink writing (DIW) process were established. Knowledge of electric-field-assisted DIW hardware design and development, manufacturing process planning and control, and manufacturing quality monitoring and characterization were developed. In addition, this project also collected experimental data and established theoretical models and machine learning models, which revealed the intricate linkages among the liquid ink rheological properties, DIW printing process parameters, and fabrication performance such as ink printing stability, resolution, and speed.  Various test cases were fabricated using the manufacturing knowledge and setup established in this project. Examples include successful printings of low viscosity inks that were traditionally difficult to print using DIW, biocompatible transparent filament composite inks, and conducting polymer inks on a diverse range of substrates such as smooth glass slides, flexible films, and super rough fabrics.   

 

Outcomes- Broader Impacts:

This project developed knowledge of electrowetting and ink deposition control, which could be applied to not just direct ink writing processes, but also many other manufacturing processes that involve droplet or liquid filament. The discoveries of this project enables innovations in printing device design and promotes new applications of direct ink writing in a number of fields and industries.  Research outcomes have been integrated into the PIs’ courses such as “ME/IE 481 Additive Manufacturing Processes”, “IE/ME 596 Independent Study”, “IE/ME 392 Undergraduate Research”, and “ME594 Transport Phenomena in Micro- and Nanotechnology”.  Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were recruited to work on this project and being trained, including students from under-represented groups and low-income families.  Among them, two PhD students graduated with dissertations developed or partially developed from this project.  More than ten journal papers were developed from this research and have been published.  A patent application was developed from this research.  Furthermore, the project results were disseminated widely to research communities through conferences and seminars and the general public through lab tours and news coverages.  

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2023
Modified by: Yayue Pan
